content: Access to clean water and sanitation is improving, but remains a major problem.
!Deaths per capita taken from the Global Burden of Disease database[disease_burden], with overall population figures supplied by the World Bank [wb_pop].

sections.name: Clean Water Access
content: Access to clean water, defined as access to an improved water source or access to a safe drinking water supply, is improving but is still far from universal.
!Sources: World Bank [wb_water] and WHO/UNICEF [safe_drinking_water], via Our World in Data [owid_water].

Although clean water challenges are concentrated in low-income countries, high-income countries are not immune. An estimated 1.6 million people in the United States lack indoor plumbing facilities [us_water_access].

sections.name: Providing Clean Water
content: The cost of providing universal clean water access has been estimated at $1.04 trillion annually as follows.
These figures are more comprehensive than some other estimates and hence larger [clean_water_cost1][clean_water_cost2].
The benefit-cost ratio of basic water supply has been estimated at 6.8 [water_copenhagen], 5.5 for access to sanitation [who_water], and 2.0 for access to improved drinking water sources [who_water].
